title: If a high school teacher screwed the class over (grade-wise) by giving super unreasonable tests, should I include this in my college application’s additional comment section? If not, do you have any suggestions? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you have a particularly low grade in one class, and all the rest of your grades are high (say a D among a field of As), you should comment on it. You should NOT, under any circumstances, blame a teacher for your bad grade. You should acknowledge that the class was really challenging for you, and that you worked hard to try to get a good grade but came up short. This taught you about the importance of time management, preparedness, developing good study habits, whatever. Basically, take this negative and spin it into a positive. You’ve experienced a failure despite trying your best. What did you learn? How will you take that forward in your studies? Don’t play the blame game though. Ultimately your grade is your responsibility, and doing poorly is no one’s fault but yours (as far as anyone reviewing applications is concerned, at least). The only case where this might not be true is if there is a documented case against this teacher where the grades were assigned unfairly based on gender or race or some other type of discrimination and you were victim to this behavior. In this case the teacher was probably fired for cause and/or there is some type of documentation with the school regarding this. It would then be appropriate to ask an administrator of the school, perhaps your counselor or a principal, to include a letter with your application explaining the circumstances of the bad grade (though I would expect that the grade would not have been allowed to stand in such circumstances).

(1) “If a high school teacher screwed the class over (grade-wise) by giving super unreasonable tests, should I include this in my college application’s additional comment section?” Only if you want to come across as a whiner. Before you consider accusing one of your teachers of administering unreasonably difficult tests on your college application, you should ask yourself the following questions: Will the college admissions officers who are reviewing my application naturally tend to side more with (a) students, or (b) teachers?Will the college admissions officers who are reviewing my application be more inclined to (a) credit my assessment that the tests were unreasonable, or (b) believe that I’m exaggerating the difficulty level in order to justify a bad grade?In other words … Even if your assessment of this teacher is accurate, there’s not a chance in the universe the admissions officers will believe you. Nothing good can come from complaining about your former teacher on a college application. You will draw attention to your failures, rather than your successes. You will come across as being a negative person. You will come across as being a person who shifts blame to other people instead of accepting responsibility. Don’t do it. (2) “If not, do you have any suggestions?” Focus on your successes, not your failures. If there’s something in your transcript that requires explanation, the only kind of explanation that will have any impact on the admissions committee will have to be based on verifiable facts, not your own unsupported opinion.
